questions.text: Which of the following statements about diverticulitis is incorrect? Diverticulitis often presents with abdominal pain localized to the lower left side. A barium enema is a preferred imaging method for diagnosing diverticulitis. Colostomy is often performed as a first-line treatment. Stage Ib of the Modified Hinchey Classification refers to a pericolic abscess. Complications of diverticulitis may include fistula formation, such as colovesical fistula.
questions.explanation:
Definition

Inflammation or infection of diverticula in the colon.

Etiology
  • Obstruction (fecal matter or food): Trapped fecal matter or food causes pressure and inflammation.
  • Bacterial infection: Infection occurs when bacteria proliferate in obstructed diverticula.

Pathophysiology
  • Increased pressure from trapped fecal matter can lead to inflammation, infection, and sometimes perforation of the diverticula.

Symptoms
  • Abdominal pain (lower left side) (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • Fever
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Change in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation)
  • Tenderness on examination

Diagnosis
  • CT Scan (IOC): Preferred for detailed imaging of the colon, identifying inflammation and abscesses.
  • Ultrasound: Can detect inflammation and abscesses, but less detailed than CT.
  • Blood Tests: Elevated white blood cell count suggests infection or inflammation.
  • Barium Enema (contraindicated) (Statement 2): Should be avoided as it can worsen symptoms.

Management
  • Antibiotics
  • Pain management (analgesics)
  • Dietary modifications (clear liquids, then low-fiber, high-fiber)
 

Surgery (for severe cases or complications)

  • Resection: Removal of the affected segment of the colon to treat severe diverticulitis or complications.
  • Colostomy (Statement 3): Creation of an abdominal opening for waste elimination, often used in severe cases.
  • Drainage of Abscesses: Percutaneous or surgical methods to drain abscesses associated with diverticulitis.

Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis)
  • Stage 0: Mild diverticulitis
  • Stage I:
    • Ia: Pericolic inflammation
    • Ib: Pericolic abscess (Statement 4 ruled out)
  • Stage II: Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess
  • Stage III: Purulent peritonitis
  • Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis

Complications
  • Hemorrhage (painless and profuse)
  • Perforation (can cause pericolic abscess)
  • Intestinal Obstruction (large or small bowel)
  • Fistula Formation (e.g., colovesical) (Statement 5 ruled out)
  • Leads to frequent UTIs, fecaluria, pneumaturia

questions.text: Which variant of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis is associated with both colorectal cancer and brain tumors?
questions.explanation:
Classic FAP (Option A)

Most common form with extensive polyps

Attenuated FAP (Option B)

Milder form with fewer polyps

Gardner syndrome (Option C)

Classic FAP + additional tumors

Turcot syndrome (Option D)

FAP variant with brain tumor

Gardner Syndrome

Turcot Syndrome
  • Autosomal dominant variant
  • Autosomal recessive variant

Associated with

  • Osteoma
  • Congenital Hypertrophy of retinal Pigment Epithelium(CHRPE)
  • Desmoid tumor
  • Epidermoid cyst
  • Supernumerary teeth
  • Benign lymphoid polyposis of ileum
  • Sebaceous cyst

Associated with brain tumors in both FAP and lynch syndrome

  • In FAP, causes Medulloblastoma.
  • In lynch syndrome, causes Glioblastoma multiforme.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent colorectal cancer. Her family history reveals that her mother was diagnosed with endometrial cancer at age 50, and her aunt had ovarian cancer. Genetic testing is recommended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Amsterdam II Criteria
  • Three or more family members with Lynch syndrome related cancer, one of whom is a 1° relative.
  • Two or more successive affected generations.
  • At least one tumor diagnosed before 50 years.
  • FAP excluded

On examination, multiple small, wart-like growths on her hands is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient is taken for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following structures is most likely to be visualized first to differentiate between small intestine and large intestine obstruction?

A 60-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. A CT scan reveals a large intestinal obstruction at the level of the descending colon. Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for providing collateral circulation in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Cecum

Connects to the ileum via the ileocecal valve, located in the lower right abdomen.

Ascending Colon

Runs upward on the right side of the abdomen to the hepatic flexure.

Transverse Colon

Extends horizontally across the abdomen from the hepatic flexure to the splenic flexure.

Descending Colon

Travels downward on the left side from the splenic flexure to the sigmoid colon.

Sigmoid Colon

S-shaped section connecting the descending colon to the rectum.

Rectum

Stores fecal matter before expulsion.

Anus

Terminal part of the digestive tract, through which feces are expelled.

Blood and Nerve supply of the Large Intestine

Arterial Supply
  • Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA): Supplies the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon. (Option A)
  • Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA): Supplies the distal one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum. (Option B)
  • Marginal Artery of Drummond: An important arterial anastomosis running along the inner border of the colon, connecting branches of the SMA and IMA, ensuring continuous blood supply and providing collateral circulation. (Option C)
  • Arc of Riolan / Meandering mesenteric artery: It is a collateral branch running close to the mesentery, connecting superior mesenteric artery to inferior mesenteric artery. It also connects proximal part of middle colic artery to left colic artery(Option D)


 

Venous Drainage

Blood from the colon drains into the superior mesenteric vein and inferior mesenteric vein, which then drain into the portal vein leading to the liver.

Lymphatic Drainage

Lymph from the colon drains into the mesenteric lymph nodes and ultimately into the thoracic duct.

Nerve Supply

Parasympathetic Supply:

  • Vagus nerve: Up to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.
  • Pelvic splanchnic nerves: From the distal one-third of the transverse colon onward.

Sympathetic Supply:

Superior and inferior mesenteric plexuses.

questions.text: Assertion: The colon plays a significant role in the production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) from dietary fibers. Reason: Fermentation of dietary fibers by gut bacteria in the colon produces SCFAs like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The Assertion is true, but the Reason is false.

options.label: D
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
questions.explanation:
Function

Description

Water and Electrolyte Absorption

Absorbs water, sodium (Na+), and chloride (Cl-) to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

Secretion

Secretes potassium (K+), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and mucus to protect mucosa and facilitate fecal passage.

Fermentation and SCFA Production
  • Ferments dietary fibers to produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) like butyrate, acetate, and propionate, which serve as metabolic fuel for colon cells.
  • The right colon, particularly the cecum, is the primary fermentation site. (Option A)

Storage and Dehydration of Stool

The left colon stores fecal matter and absorbs water to form solid stools.

Vitamin Production

Gut bacteria synthesize vitamins such as vitamin K and some B vitamins, which are absorbed by the colon.

Protection and Immunity

Provides a barrier against pathogens through mucus, epithelial tight junctions, and immune cells.

Motility and Transit
  • Exhibits peristaltic movements to mix contents and move them toward the rectum.
  • Mass peristalsis propels fecal matter for defecation.

Regulation of pH

Absorbs SCFAs and secretes bicarbonate to maintain optimal pH for bacterial activity and colonic function.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, and a digital rectal examination reveals a tight anal sphincter with an explosive discharge of stool upon withdrawal of the finger. What is the best step of investigation to confirm the exact pathology?
questions.explanation:
Introduction

Congenital disorder known as congenital aganglionic megacolon or aganglionosis.

Pathophysiology
  • Absence of ganglion cells in myenteric (Auerbach) and submucosal (Meissner) plexuses.
  • Continuous contraction of the affected bowel segment, leading to functional obstruction.
  • Leads to proximal bowel dilatation and hypertrophy due to chronic obstruction.
  • Typically affects the rectosigmoid region but can involve the entire colon in severe cases.

CLINICAL PRESENTATION

Neonates:
  • Failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours.
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Bilious vomiting

Infants and Children
  • Chronic constipation
  • Poor feeding
  • Failure to thrive
  • Enterocolitis (fever, diarrhea, and abdominal distension)

DIAGNOSIS

Clinical Evaluation

History and physical examination indicating chronic constipation and failure to pass meconium.

Radiological

Abdominal X-ray: Shows dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels. (Option A)
 

Contrast (Barium) Enema: Demonstrates a transition zone between dilated proximal and narrow distal bowel. (Option B)

Rectal Biopsy

Gold standard and IOC for diagnosis, showing the absence of ganglion cells. (Option C)

Anorectal Manometry

Shows lack of rectoanal inhibitory reflex. (Option D)

MANAGEMENT

Initial Management
  • Stabilization with fluid resuscitation and decompression of the colon.
  • Antibiotics for enterocolitis if present.

Definitive Surgical Treatment
  • Pull-Through Procedures: Removal of the aganglionic segment and pulling through the normal bowel to the anus.
  • Swenson Procedure: Resection of the aganglionic segment with anastomosis to the anus.
  • Duhamel Procedure: Ganglionic bowel brought down behind the aganglionic segment, side-to-side anastomosis.
  • Soave Procedure: Removing the mucosa of the aganglionic segment, pulling the ganglionic bowel through the muscular cuff.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing. He gives a history of gastrointestinal discomfort and was recently diagnosed with both hiatal hernia and diverticulosis during a routine endoscopic examination. Given his current history, what is the other condition that has the highest probability for which he should be evaluated?

A 55-year-old patient presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. A barium enema is performed, which reveals a characteristic finding on imaging given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Etiology
  • Diet: Low-fiber diet increases colon pressure.
  • Age: More common in those over 60.
  • Genetics: Family history may increase risk.

Pathophysiology
  • Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge.
  • Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

Characteristics
  • False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital.
  • Location: Most commonly in the sigmoid colon, along the mesenteric aspect.

Symptoms
  • Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

(Option A)
  • Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.
  • CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.
  • Barium enema: Less common, show a characteristic sawtooth appearance

Management
  • Diet: Increase fiber intake.
  • Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids.
  • Exercise: Promotes healthy bowel function.

Complications
  • Lower GI Bleed: Common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies a type of non-neoplastic polyp?
questions.explanation:
Neoplastic Polyps

Non-Neoplastic Polyps

Adenomatous Polyps (Adenomas)

  • Tubular (Option A)
  • Villous (Option D)
  • Tubulovillous

Inflammatory Polyps

Associated with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

Serrated Polyps

  • Hyperplastic Polyps
  • Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA/Ps) (Option B)
  • Traditional Serrated Adenomas (TSAs)

Hamartomatous Polyps

  • Juvenile Polyps: Usually in children, generally benign but associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome. (Option C)
 
  • Peutz-Jeghers Polyps: Associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by pigmentation around the mouth.
 

Lymphoid Polyps

Composed of lymphoid tissue, usually benign and associated with the immune response
